Nisemonogatari. 
Bakemonogatari ended on some pleasant note. I was really willing to know more about what was gonna happen next. So... what do we have from Nisemonogatari. 
Basically, happened what I had feared. It's become more haremish. If we were to cut the fanservice part, it would remain like 1\3. I think it's gone a bit too far. Furthermore, it reminds of a harem even more. Now, when Araragi's sisters so much involved. And now, when Araragi flirts with them throughout the whole show. 
The plot itself here is rather simple, almost nothing significant happens, besides we get to know new characters. Also, Shinobu. Shebegins to transform from the furniture into a remnant of the legendary vampire who at long last finds herself quite bored. 


Araragi wasn't that much consistent with his words from the very beginning but here, he feels even more inconsistent. That refers to his actions as well. I don't know, for me he felt more, like, noble in previous shows. 

Another characters feel slightly different as well. Though, I'm all right with it because it may count for their developments. In case with Koyomi it's more like a degradation rather than a development. 


Visually it's just great as always. I'm almost got used to it. However, it often manages to satisfy my eye with new undiscovered ways.  It is odd. It is good. Even though, monogatari series concentrates on dialogues, it doesn't prevent it to have ridiculously good fighting scenes. Nisemonogatari isn't an exception. 

Same applies to the sound. OP-s and ED-s are great. My personal favourite is the third OP with Tsukihi. 

At least, these two aspects don't upset me. 


As a conclusion, I might say I don't like the turn monogatari series took. I'm sure it can offer much more, something more valuable than just sisters' fanservice. 

I just hope the next show in the series will refrain from it. 


If you're alike me watching monogatari series the show after the show I guess there's no point in skipping this one, yet... well, see it and have your own judgment.

The first season that was Bakemonogatari is my #5 anime of all time.
How does the follow-up Nisemonogatari rate so poorly?
Fan service can be good in moderation. I'm one of the types that understands its appeal but wow the amount of excessive, over the top fan service went way overboard here. What is known as the "toothbrush" scene is a clear example of getting really excessive with the fan service.
This could have been due to covering up the fact that the first arc spanned 7 of the 11 episodes. The first arc went at a snails pace compared to the whole Bakemonogatari. Half of those episodesfelt like filler.


The character development of almost all the characters felt stagnant compared to Bakemonogatari. Many of the females only existed for fan service compared to Bakemonogatari, when there was a solid balance between character development and fan service. Some of the characters also suddenly change their personality to either fit fan service or to suddenly fit the plot.


The only new characters which are the main character's sisters aren't nearly as polished as many of the characters in the original. The season focuses on them and it doesn't have nearly as much depth. Somehow the dialogue feels shallow, especially compared to Bakemonogatari.


The art is above average but actually not up to full SHAFT standards. It doesn't have the magical touch that Bakemonogatari has.


Some highlights that give it some points: 

Hitagi is a signature yandere as the opening scene proves this.

Some scenes gave that signature SHAFT excitement


Those two items bring it up to 4.

Sequels are usually a thing that can either make or break a story. Some are intended to fill up the incompleteness its predecessor had, while some are pretty much cash grabs used to milk off the franchise.
The latter reception is often given to Nisemonogatari, the follow-up to the 2009 cult hit Bakemonogatari, originally based off a light novel series by Nisio Isin. This series covers the second arc of the light novels, running around the theme of what is fake and what is real.
Nise consists of two story arcs that are presented in 11 episodes, which cover the aftermath of Bake and the entry ofnew characters to spice up the world of aberrations. Our protagonist, Koyomi Araragi, resident pedophile and harem master, encounters new challenges that would only affect him, but also the inclusion of his sisters Karen and Tsukihi.


The first arc, Karen Bee, focuses on his elder younger sister, Karen, and the similarities they have in their resolve. This arc was pretty interesting that it also covers more ground with the other main characters from the previous arc, such as Sengoku, Suruga, and most especially Hanekawa, who ditched the long hair and glasses to disappoint the huge megane fanbase. The introduction of a new character, Kaiki, also brings up some interesting conflict into the philosophies of both Araragi and Senjougahara, and how the latter finally comes into terms with her past. The whole arc is filled with many character interactions, and Shinobu finally speaking after having no voice actress for Bake shows a lot into Araragi and her connection as master and servant.


Meanwhile, the second arc falls short due to its five-episode length and barely brings focus to the youngest sister, Tsukihi, save for the final few episodes. While it is kind of disappointing to have less screen time, her role in the arc cannot certainly be ignored as it puts up a great development with Araragi and Shinobu, and, uh...Karen, I guess.


The criticisms often thrown at Nise are its excessive and gratuitous fanservice, to the point that it's really uncomfortable to watch. But to be honest, it was definitely more wholesome than Bake. Nise has this feel of continuity while Bake works on introducing the characters and their traits and connections to the protagonist, giving the former a greater sense to develop these relationships through the classic Monogatari method of lengthy dialogue. The style of artistic narration is a big difference to Bake, which is the reason for its criticism. Nise seemed to appeal more to the audience through sexy camera angles that contrast with the overall theme of the franchise. While I couldn't argue with that, Nise is still more enjoyable to watch, thanks to the existing relationships and inclusion of new people into the plot.


The animation is made by Shaft, already well-known for its surreal and arthouse-like anime such as Bakemonogatari and Puella Magi Madoka Magica. I would like to give a job well done for the studio as they produced according to what they were going for. The thing with fanservice is, it's sometimes really weird to watch, and seeing it on screen emits an awkward effect for the viewers. However, Nise was one of the few times I enjoyed watching fanservice because it handles it in a provocative and different approach rather than just straight-up putting your hormones into overload. Nise has also more action than the previous entry, and while that has never been the focus of the Monogatari series it was a nice addition to the over-the-top style of mish-mash feel the animation has.


---

Toothbrush Thoughts


The infamous toothbrush scene of Episode 8 may be one of the most controversial scenes in recent anime history, and that is true to this day.


To put into context, the main character Koyomi's sister Karen demands him that he introduce her to Suruga, who is a known basketball player in their area (Karen is a martial artist, something that's also within the field of sports). In order to test her, Koyomi challenges Karen to survive five minutes of getting her teeth brushed...by him.


I wouldn't go explaining further, but as much as disgusting it may look on the outside, it was pretty amusing and educational. For one, I learned that brushing someone else's teeth has a psychological effect because you're not the one brushing your own teeth.


As for implications of incest wincest, eeeeehhhh whatever. It's not like the Monogatari series was mild to begin with.


Tl;dr I liked the scene.

---


The soundtrack adds well to the feel of Monogatari being Monogatari, from the catchy opening songs (of which special mention goes to the third OP, Platinum Disco) and the background music that goes along well with the visual direction of the show. The voice actors were impressive as usual, and Maaya Sakamoto as Shinobu was a welcome addition to the voice cast. The dialogue is one of the strongest points of Monogatari, and it's not just because of the writing but also because of the emotion all these seiyuus put into their characters.


I welcome Nisemonogatari into the franchise as much as the 2009 adaptation. It may be not one of the best entries, but it gave me more reason to love the series as more of its potential is explored. Is it a cash grab? Maybe. But it wasn't that bad of a show.

Compared to it's first season, this anime was a lot lighter, funner and had much more humour. Part of me actually was wondering if they were trying to appeal to a different, younger crowd instead of keeping what made its original so.. unique. 
On that note though, it's not like I didnt enjoy it. It still  had it's witty dialogues and crazy story lines that kept me more than interested... however, I feel like they lost sight of a lot of the characters personalities and went a little over board. Senjogahara, the usual cold, Tsudere type has become more talkative and kinda underwhelming, Ididnt really understand why she would submit to Hanekawa so easily.. but I guess that's just the way they chose to go with it. Araragi, has become more popular with the girls, that was evident in the first season.. however again, his character almost develops into something unrecognizable as he was a lot more perverted and into playing that playboy role.. even though he's in a relationship. \n\n
Meeting the sisters were also a nice new fresh touch to this season, but I feel like more time was spent on Karen then the younger sister, when technically the younger sisters story line could have been taken more seriously than the hornet. But that's just my opinion.

Well....where do I start with this one. To get it out of the way, i dont like incest and pedo fanservice. imo, just because its animated doesn't make it better, the idea itself is gross and I feel its meant to be a scapegoat for people so they feel they arent doing anything morally wrong for enojying it because its "animated". To start off with Karen Bee, I think the arc maintained the charm the bakemonogatari series had. Some complained it was drawn out but pacing didnt feel like an issue for me. 


The main issue was Tsukihi Phoenix. Now, I havent read the light novels. I was excited for this arc, as tsukihi as a character interested me. Boy was I dissapointed. Now, I'll be honest here. I dropped Nisemonogatari when I first watched it. I came in expecting the next Bakemonogatari, what I ended up getting was completely different, and I dropped it. I even went so far as to declare the series dead in my eyes: that nothing would ever come close to the excellence of its predecessor, and it was a waste to even expect something decent anymore.
It took only one forum thread full of disagreeing people to change my mind. I quickly got my hands on the Blu-rays and got to watching; this time not expecting anything but disappointment. Now that I'm finished,this is my conception.


Bakemonogatari and Nisemonogatari are equal. They're just better at some things and worse at others.


Nisemonogatari follows our resident high-schooler/pseudo-vampire/pedophile Araragi Koyomi shortly after the events of Bakemonogatari. Having rid five girls of their respective oddities in the last season, Araragi doesn't seem to have any urgent business to attend to. And it shows, especially in the first few episodes, which are nothing but Araragi screwing around with his friends and sisters. The plot only really begins to be explored around the fourth episode, where the first main antagonist (a con man named Kaiki Deishuu), is revealed and introduced. This story structure is why I was initially disappointed. Nisemonogatari, at least for the first few episodes, has almost no sense of urgency, something that was in abundance in Bakemonogatari. A problem is not introduced until at least the fourth episode, and the episodes leading up to this revelation are not full of foreshadowing and anticipation, but sexual comedy and assorted antics. Even after the problem is introduced, the sense of urgency doesn't really return like you'd expect, and the issue itself is approached and solved through more of the same: sexual comedy and assorted antics. The show only truly becomes intense during the final climax, which is where I found the most to love. If you're looking for serious, critical situations for our main protagonist to be thrown into, you will surely be disappointed; at least for a little while.


But within this weakness of a slow start lies Nisemonogatari's greatest strength: its dialogue. The conversations some of these characters have with each other are insane; employing copious amounts of jokes, wordplays, and references, all at blindingly fast speed. These numerous and extremely entertaining exchanges were not missing in Bakemonogatari, but because Bake focused much more on the mythology behind and ramifications of the respective oddities, there was much less room for these sorts of discussions than there was in the void of happenings that ruled Nise's first few chapters. What it comes down to is that if hilarious dialogues spoken in the oratory equivalent of rapid-fire sounds like something you'd be interested in, I'd implore you to watch this; especially so if you dropped it early because of the fan-service. These interactions will not leave you disappointed.


Something that has not changed from Bake to Nise is the quality of the art and sound. The art, done in the customary SHAFT fashion, with many abstract windows, objects, and designs, is truly a sight to behold in Nisemonogatari. The character art, again, is impeccable, with special mention going to the animation of Araragi's myriad of facial features, which really hit home with me and brought on more than a few laughs over the course of the show. The soundtrack is fantastic, with the OST's multiple styles being some of the highlights of Araragi's numerous fantastical adventures, typically melding to fit the mood of the scene, whether it be serious and pressing or cordial and casual. The voice acting steals the show once more, with exceptional deliveries coming from Kamiya Hiroshi (Araragi), Kitamura Eri (Karen), and Iguchi Yuka (Tsukihi). Once more, the obvious star is Kamiya Hiroshi, whose over the top line deliveries allow Araragi's dialogue to take on nearly a life of its own at some points. My only quip was the lack of catchy opening and ending songs. Naisho no Hanashi, the ending performed by Claris, was fine but not great, and neither of the two openings really appealed to me either. I guess we can't always have a Kimi no Shiranai Monogatari level ending, or a staple stable level opening, but for a highly anticipated sequel such as this, I expected just a bit more.


The characters, while not the most deep and developed you will ever see, run the gambit and get the job done. The standout this season is not Araragi, actually, but rather Senjougahara, whose gradual change from tsundere sadist to regular, caring girl, can be seen here, despite her lack of screen-time compared to the last season. Everyone else is pretty much unchanged from Bakemonogatari, with the exception of Araragi's sisters, Karen and Tsukihi (which are developed exponentially and are given a much larger role), and Araragi himself, who has gone from slightly sexually frustrated do-gooder (who is occasionally perverted) to complete pervert, which isn't my favorite character transformation, but allows for many more entertaining and embarrassing exchanges between him and his friends, which, as I argued above, is really the core of this show. So in that regard, the change works, and I think the show is better for it.


Nisemonogatari is far from the sexually charged fan-service-y trash I initially labeled it. It is indeed sexually charged, but it takes that charge and applies it to the fastest, most entertaining exchanges I've seen between characters since Hyouka, the funniest characters I've had the pleasure of watching in a long time, the most passionate voice acting I've heard since Steins;Gate, and a very beautiful art style that blurs the line between background and abstract painting. If you haven't watched this yet, if you've been putting it off because you've heard unflattering things, or if, like me, you dropped it prematurely... let me be the one to tell you: this show is not Bakemonogatari. Arguably, it is nothing even close. But it is witty, funny, entertaining... and definitely worth your time.

This Review is out of 100. 35/100 for Story, 35/100 for Characters, 15/100 for Sound, 15/100 for Animation. 
Story - 23/35 - The story isn't bad, but it is noticeably worse than Bakemonogatari. Since there are only 2 stories instead of 5, there is a lot more "filler" than there was in Bakemono. Even the filler is worse. A lot of the filler is fanservice, and there is much much more in this show than the last. The only good fanservice to come out of this show was the toothbrush scene (Don't judge me). The stories themselves are just as good in my opinion, justtoo long. This show probably could have been 6 episodes long instead is 11, which tells you how much filler there is. I liked the ending for each arc, and how they were tied together in the end. 


Characters - 25/35 - Bakemonogatari was good because of it's characters. In Nisemonogatari, all those characters are there, they just take even more of a back seat. My two favorite girls, Hitagi and Kanbaru, are even less important now. Araragi is even weirder than he was before, sexually harassing both his sisters multiple times. Because of this, I found his character to be less enjoyable in this show. His sisters were very fun though, as were the villains. 


Sound - 12/15 - Because there is only 2 girls, there were less openings. They were still very good, but in this case less isn't more. The background music didn't sound much better than that in Bakemonogatari. Overall there really isn't much to say here. 


Animation 12/15 This was a big step up from Bakemonogatari. None of those stupid flashing screens with words anymore. Thank you. It would be perfect if the scenes weren't so oversexualized. Just like how the story had more fanservice than its predecessor, this show had way more sexual scenes. For example, Araragi's sister bent down to pick him up, so of course the show has to give us a close up of her ass and crotch. Things like this arent story related and I feel have more to do with the animation decisions. 


Overall - 72/100 - Both the story and the characters take a hit in Nisemonogatari, while the animation gets a much needed bump. The story here was the biggest letdown. While the Fire Sisters and the Villains keep the characters interesting, the sheer amount of fanservice and filler hinder the story way too much.

The Monogatari series, the story of half-vampire high school student Koyomi Arararararagi (sorry, I stuttered) and his sort-of harem of girls with various magical and spiritual afflictions, is a series of ups and down, containing some of my favorite and least favorite moments in all of anime. On the one hand, it's gorgeously animated and directed, taking full advantage of its medium to constantly keep you entertained with creative colors, cuts, and camera angles. On the other, it's remarkably up its own ass, sometimes to its benefit, sometimes to its detriment. On the one hand, it contains my absolute favorite relationship in all of anime.On the other, it thinks groping elementary-school girls is an acceptable running joke. It's a series of ideas and imagination that spring and explode in every which way, achieving brilliance just as often as it gets tangled in itself. Nisemonogatari, the second installment in the franchise, perfectly embodies this dichotomy.


The story here is told in two arcs, each one focusing on one of Araragi's sisters: Karen and Tsukihi. The first arc, centered around Karen's classmates suffering at the hands of a magical con man and her desire to take justice into her own hands, is Monogatari firing on all cylinders. The story weaves in Araragi's conflicted feelings about his sister's do-gooding as it relates to his own, Senjougahara's still-festering demons of the past, their constantly evolving, always delightful relationship dynamic, and themes about what the "true" way to be just is and what it means to be fake. It hits hard and fast with comedy and drama alike, weaving together complex streams of thought and dialogue into a rich tapestry that deepens Karen and Araragi's sibling bond and enriches both their characters. It even manages to do fanservice alright, aforementioned kid-groping nonwithstanding. It's highly entertaining and always engaging, marking a high point for the franchise.


The second arc, centered on Tsukihi's newly discovered magical malady, is utter garbage.


There are a lot of reasons for that, but the biggest one is the fact that the entire first episode of the arc isn't focused on Tsukihi at all. Instead, it's focused on INCEST. That's right, that powerful sibling bond that Karen and Araragi just developed suddenly takes a turn for the perverted, with the whole episode spent on Araragi lusting after her, trying to deny his lust for her, and the show ogling her at every chance it can, climaxing (for lack of a less uncomfortable phrase) with him basically fucking her with a toothbrush. It's not funny, it's not clever, it's not interesting, and it made me want to vomit. To this day, it's the single most unpleasant anime-watching experience I've ever had, and I wish I could scrub it from my memory.


Even beyond that horrible experience, though, the rest of the arc (only 4 episodes compared to Karen's 7) just isn't interesting. Tsukihi isn't even a character in her own story, spending all her time with various characters arguing about and over her while she lies unconscious thanks to her affliction. She's an object, something to be fought over by everyone else, not a character in her own right. There's no investment in it because we don't know enough about Tsukihi to care about her. Oh, but the show does find time for Araragi to strip her naked and grope her breasts before she goes all Sleeping Beauty, because of fucking COURSE it does. Who cares about actually developing her as a character when we can just imagine being her lord and master Onii-Chan?


As you can tell, I am very divided on this one. Considering it sets up future characters and events, I can't very well recommend skipping Tsukihi's arc. It is part of Monogatari, as much as I wish it wasn't. But that's the give and take with this franchise. You're bounced around between brilliance and bullshit, and you do your best to admire the (admittedly much more frequent) good stuff before it drops you into shit again. In that way, Nisemonogatari is very much the series' standard bearer, for better and worse. But at the very least, it gave me plenty of Senjougahara being the fucking best, so I guess I can't complain too much.


Well, I actually can, but whatever.

*THE RATINGS FOR THIS ARE SPECIFIC TO THE PART, BUT THE REVIEW IS FOR THE OVERALL SERIES*
[STORY: 10/10]
The Monogatiri series comes together well to create a masterpiece of a story. This show is much deeper than alot of people think. It is filled to the brim with philosophical arguments and great storytelling. The focus isn't mainly on action, though it does have some visually stunning action scenes. Alot of the time, it will just be conversations between characters, but this is the blood that keeps this series alive and flourishing. Without it, you'd have a normal show with above average production. This type of showisn't for everyone, but I personally love it.


[ART: 10/10]

The animators went all out animating this show, as detail and flamboyance embody the artistic direction of this show. Each character's design and set piece is carefully planned out, and it shows. 


[SOUND: 10/10]

The voice actors become their characters when they act them out, that's how into them they get. They really care about their role, you can tell. And sound effects are well done as well, nothing seems off in that department.


[CHARACTER: 10/10]

Most every character is important to the main plot of the story and if they aren't a main character, the style of the show makes it seem as if they don't even exist. Whether they be designed as set pieces or outlines, the show really puts emphasis on those we really care about. These characters are no joke either, pretty much none of them are one-dimensional wastes of time, which is very appeciated.


[ENJOYMENT/OVERALL: 10/10]

Though some parts of the series are better than others, the series as a whole is truly an amazing body of work that I consider a masterpiece. This story is filled to the brim with beautifully crafted characters, artwork, sound design, and an amazing story that philosophically challenges the observer to think. A masterful work by Isin Nisio.

After waiting what i now know to be far too long. I have finished Nisemonogatari. And wow was that a ton better than Bakemongatari. Like wow.
Not to knock Bake really, but it was very rough around the edges for me. Had a lot of good ideas and laid a lot of solid groundwork, i just felt it didn't do as much as it could've in 15 episodes. Still enjoyed it. Had lot of great moments, Ep 12 and Ep 15 being absolutely amazing. But it still felt like it stumbled hard in those first 6 to 8 episodes.
Anyways, Nise took everything Bake did and everythingBake introduced and made it so much better.


Araragi is now one of my absolute favorite characters in anime, at least top 20 or something like that. He really came into his own this time, in Bake he felt more like a plot device than an actual character in his own right. Like he just served to solve the girl's problems and nothing more. However, in Nise, he actually showed a ton of personality and depth. He had some great wit and sarcasm that was a joy to watch. Then he had some great emotional moments too with his sisters and with Hachikuji and with Shinobu.


His loyalty to his sisters was amazing. His speech to Karen in Ep 7 was perfect in every way. In fact, any time he spoke to Karen about her ans Tsukihi about the two of them being the Fire Sisters was awesome to see. The dynamic the three of them had was incredible and automatically believable.


Speaking of the Fire Sisters, i think Nise being focused around them was partially what made it so much more enjoyable for me. As any time they were on screen it was such a treat to watch. Karen was especially cool with her interactions with Koyomi being cute and sweet sibling interactions. Tsukihi was a sweety too. Her arc in the later part was great and worked well.


But by far Karen Bee was more enjoyable than Tsukihi Phoenix for me. Actually, now i'd call Karen Bee my favorite arc so far as having Kaiki in there mixed things up. Having an actual tangible "villain" in there was good. As it wasn't just some random supernatural creature we didn't really see until like the end of the arc or something. Tsukihi Phoenix was fine. Not bad. but not really great either. Ononoki and Kagenui were decent enough "villains" but not too noteworthy for me. They were serviceable, which was fine for me at the end of the day.


The first 4 or 5 eps of Nise were really amazing all the around. The direction, the colors, the dialogue, the cinematography were all amped up it seemed. Like within the first 5 or 10 minutes of ep 1 i know this was going to be much better than Bake. The reintroduction of the previous girls, Hanekawa, Senjougahara, Kanbaru, Hachikuji, and Sengoku was pretty great. All getting a solid scene to put them back into perspective.


Of the previously introduced girls Hachikuji and Sengoku certainly got a step up. The scene were Araragi goes to Sengoku's house was pretty darn adorable honestly. Her crush on him is the cutest thing. Like holy hell. Adorable.


Hachikuji had some great conversations with Araragi all throughout Nise really. She was a great confidant for Araragi to have. Her purposely saying his name wrong is equally cute too. Ararararararagi.


Hanakawa........Hanakawa......well now. She's like so damn good. Like shit. She may have had only a small bit to do in Nise, but wowzers did she make the most of it really. Helping Karen and Tsukihi out with their problem was sweet and somewhat motherly. She was just as good as Bake for me. Didn't miss a step at all.


Now, when it comes to Shinobu...she was so damn good!!!! Love her! She's awesome! Like hell, she's great. The bath scene with her and Araragi was a perfect scene. The conversations she had wit Araragi throughout Nise were all solid scenes. Her little love for Donuts is cute too. Her abundant confidence and absolute belief in herself is admirable and highly rspectable too. She showed a lot this time and i loved it a lot really.


Now i want to come back to Kaiki himself for a bit here. Solid "villain", he was great. The scene that introduced him with the backdrop of the red trees and red sky. OMG that was a perfect scene. Then his conversation with Araragi and Senjougahara in ep 7 was some amazing dialogue.


About the colors this time though. They were so much better too. Red is such a great color to me. Especially crimson and maroon. Of which Nise used both perfectly and to great effect.


Overall: i know i rambled a bit here and my paragraph structure isnt the best. But i think that fits Monogatari pretty damn well actually. Personally, i loved Nise. Much better than Bake. I know within about the first 10ish minutes of ep 1 that i'd enjoy this a lot more and i certainly did. Everything about Nise was just plain better. BetterMonogatari is its new name now.


A major step up.


9.5/10.

"In a way, the supernatural is what's behind the curtain. Normally, you only need to see what's happening on stage. That's how reality works. If you don't know, it's best that you don't."
--Mayoi Hachikuji
Nisemonogatari is the second installment of the now critically-acclaimed smash hit Monogatari franchise. Continuing the exploits of Koyomi Araragi from the first installment (Bakemonogatari), in this one he focuses on a much smaller group of heroines while still spending some time with the characters he and audiences grew to care for over the course of the first installment. 
Is it a worthy successor to Bakemonogatari? Well, yes and no. One of thethings that made Bakemonogatari such a smash hit was Shaft's unrestrained use of rapid-fire visual imagery to accentuate the action or dialogue on screen. Nisemonogatari follows through on this tradition, but in an oddly restrained fashion. I found myself genuinely missing the odd visuals and Japanese text scrolling at a ballistic pace across the screen, spicing up the extremely lengthy dialogues that take place throughout the series.


Visually, the art style is a direct continuation of the minimalist work in Bakemonogatari. Every frame feels very clean, and there is a lot of color contrast in just about every frame, making it easy to focus on the important actors on screen. Stark whites, deep reds, and cloying yellows are used the most, and the animation never disappoints either, showcasing Studio Shaft's unique trademarks while wowing the audience.


Just like the first installment of the series, Nisemonogatari is packing a fantastic soundtrack and score. The OPs are all listenable, but the third one, "Hakkin Disco", is a real treat. The ED song is a very high-energy, fistpumping sort of song accompanied with all sorts of chaotic visuals. Again, the voice acting is premium, as the all-star cast returns and continues to put forth powerful performances from start to finish.


The focus of Nisemonogatari's story falls to Koyomi's lovely imoutos: the "Fire Sisters", Karen and Tsukihi. While in Bakemonogatari they were barely present, here they take front and center stage, and are both afflicted with supernatural oddities that protagonist Koyomi must help them fend off and overcome. Hitagi Senjougahara, Koyomi's now-girlfriend and one of the "best girls" in all of anime, receives a bit of side focus. So too does Shinobu Oshino, the lolita vampire literally shadowing Koyomi everywhere he goes. Each of them gets some fantastic development. I went into this installment expecting to hate Karen, but she turned out to be the star of the show, in my opinion. She's a precocious, ass-kicking, firecracker of a girl, reminiscent of Rin Natsume from Little Busters! in a way.


The other new character introduced is Kaiki Deishuu, a gloomy, creepy con artist who is himself familiar with the supernatural, and his arrival in Koyomi's peaceful town is what precipitates the events of the series. Enigmatic and sinister, he captures the viewer's attention in every scene. Shinichiro Miki (Bleach, Fullmetal Alchemist) gives the man a creepy voice reeking of disdain.


One cannot discuss Nisemonogatari without mentioning the fact that yes, the fanservice has been ramped up to an almost insane degree in this installment. At some points it becomes so over-the-top that it almost devours the plot. While I'm all for showing some skin, there's a saturation point where it stops being titillating and starts becoming disturbing, and Nisemonogatari crossed that point with nothing more than a bed and a toothbrush. Make no mistake, this series earns every inch of its R-17 rating, and Koyomi is a man of very few scruples. You have been warned.


My experience with Nisemonogatari was truly a mixed bag. It wowed me in a lot of places, bored me a couple times (the first couple episodes are just recap/checking in with characters who don't appear for the rest of the season), and disturbed me a few times (erm... dental hygiene, and the geysers of blood shed in the climactic finale). I did like the philosophical tone of the season. It asks real compelling questions: Who decides what is real and what is fake? What is the value of a fake? And if something that is fake is indistinguishable from the real, is it still inherently inferior? These questions left me thinking, and that's something to cheer about. 


I wish they'd spent more time discussing these concepts and a bit less time focusing on Suruga Kanbaru's shapely ass, but that's Nisemonogatari in a nutshell: a quality continuation that excites, frustrates, and imposes some heavy cringe on the viewer, but nonetheless compels the audience to keep watching, to see what's around the next corner. Whenever you feel like you've had enough of Koyomi's perversion, there's always a sudden character appearance, a mystery hook, or a warm and touching scene to keep you invested. 


It's worth watching if Bakemonogatari managed to hold your interest the whole way through. Until next time, remember to always keep your teeth clean and your family close.

This is a particularly challenging series to rate. Nisemonogatari has the signature art, sound, humorof its predecessor. The introduction of the first episode is extremely strong with hilarious signature interaction between Araragi and Senjougahara. Then comes the gradual decent into fanservice.
The prequel Bakemonogatari was a very enjoyable series and, in all fairness, did contain a fair bit of fanservice. At some points the fanservice even teetered towards particularly distasteful. However most of the time it was fairly innocent or more often than not was used only to the extent that it legitimately supported a joke that was actually funny. I can personally tolerate fanservice eventhough I do not see the need for it - as such I did not let it bother me in the prequel to this series.


However in Nisemonogatari it is elevated to excess. While there is nothing particularly graphic there are entire episodes devoted to sexual innuendo, somewhat visual paedophillic insinuations as well as incest. Furthermore it is rarely used to support a joke, if anything weak jokes are used in what appears to be the author's attempt to cover up his warped (and illegal) sexual preferences. The issue goes beyond the inclusion of too much fanservice. The series is in fact dominated by it to the detriment of the story, humor and characters.


That being said if you don't mind the occasional naked 8 year old being thrown in your face as well as the main character's personality being butchered (which is ignored as if it never happens) and a frequent lack of story progress you may be able to enjoy this series. I wanted to, but could not.

Often I watch series because my friends tell "just try X, it has Y like your favorite Z" where X and Z were titles and Y was genre, plot, characters, art style, storytelling or many other things. Because it's quite common practice MAL have section "Recommendations". But it's difficult for now to find any anime like Monogatari series. Bakemonogatari was quite a shocker and divided audience on praisers and haters of this show. It was just unexpected for many that the story wasn't mainly based on action, romance or characters relationships. Episodes were full of word play, meaningless conversations about sexual themes and lolicon attitudesof Araragi Koyomi. But some viewers neglected this and focused on rescuing girls and fighting supernatural beings.


In Nisemonogatari there is simply no way to ignore fan service and ecchi dialogues any longer as the action quantity drops. Because of that sequel made full-of-fan-service impression although it just develops further something present in Bakemonogatari. Some scenes of sequel are very close to hentai and even lolicon. But as I tolerable to this I found no problem in completing and re-watching this show several times. Nisemonogatari is outstanding because of synergy of its story, art and sound.


Story is character-driven with postmodernist and abstract style. Nisio Isin - writer of Monogatari series ranobe - is remarkable for his breaking of fourth wall to create illusion of conscious characters. They can speak about anything - IT sector in Russia, pseudo philosophical problems, plans on future, life-long bond, someones past or underwear. They don't follow common sense or any rules and can do pretty much anything. They can reflect hours on meaningless things or make important decision in a second. This makes characters unpredictable in comparison to most of anime or literature characters.


Art is abstract and heavily used to tell the story. Captions on the road, street signs, a strand of hair to symbolize Araragi family - there are a lot of details which are incorporated in story and character design. Mind-blowing architecture, saturated colors, changing lightning conditions - it seems like artists don't wanted to draw same motionless background every frame. Some frames are heavily packed with information which make re-watching even more exciting.


Soundtrack covers several genres but mainly uses minimalistic sometimes multi-layered compositions. Sound perfectly fits the story and amplifies abstract feel of the series.


But main enjoyment of series is seeing thoughtful integration of story, art and soundtrack. I cannot imagine Nisemonogatari without any of this component altered or completely changed.

Let's make this quick, as it is my first review for an anime...
Nisemonogatari, or as I to call it "Fakely Story" is the direct sequel of Bakemonogatari, also its second season.
The story revolves around our main character Araragi (also called arararagi) , that focuses on solving problems related to *cough* girl *cough* from day to day, while either being beaten to a stick to tortured directly from one of them.
At first glance Araragi seems to be the good natured guy, who just wants to help,but as you glance deeper into this prodigy kid,you will notice that he's more of an eccentric, good natured pervert, Isuppose?


Unlike bakemonogatari (which twirled around either recently met girls, childhood friends or "non-existing" ones that were linked to any supernatural activity and/or reflected its traits), Nisemonogatari focuses more on Araragi's sisters,both being absolute *cough* *cough* Fair Ladies and some of you may ask "hey,doesn't the show focus on the relationship that this absolute idiot developes whilst having random interactions with the girls?"

and to that I answer with "yes,this is going to go into incest at some point"

As we're coming to the end of this short review,I would like to rate this anime on many various sectors.


Music/sound 7/10: 

nothing too great,just played in the background to match the watcher's emotions.

far more superior in Bakemonogatari


Story:7/10 

fairly consistent. Some little twists may confuse the viewer


Art: 10/10

 Spectacular! Magnificent! Bravo studio Shaft,you always make daddy proud (yes I am a fanboy).


Character: 8/10

Interesting to explore the "fire twins",as they were not examined in season 1


Enjoyment: 6/10 

Gets boring at times,I suggest to watch this show if have a lot of patience or like stories that develop fast yet slow in some points.

Thanks you for the fan service anyway xD!


Overall: 7.8/10


Great kudos to the art,beautifully done and good job on the interactions between the characters.


Thanks for reading this short, scruffy and boring review and sorry for any grammatical error or misspelling.

Nisemonogatari Review: Supernatural Little Sisters
Well I finished Nisemonogatari, taking it much slower than I did Bakemonogatari and I think I liked it more. This may be due to my love for shows like Oreimo and other shows having to do with little sisters, but I liked it a decent amount. So here is the review of Nisemonogatari:
This season focuses on three characters which got essentially no screen time in the first season:
Karen, Tsukihi, and Shinobu,
Now personally I loved all these characters with Shinobu being my favorite, followed by Karen, then Tsukihi. I was predisposed to Shinobu though because she is the whole reason Ieven watched this show, though I am seeing more and more that I am Araragi though not with such a sense of justice. 


The show begins with the Karen Bee arc and pretty much goes around seeing what all the other girls from Bakemonogatari are up to, and then doesn't address Sengoku or Kanbaru for the rest of the show, with the others having some roles to play. Eventually it finally brings the focus to Karen and then Shinobu, this is where the season really kicks off and gets into the funny over the top scenes lined with beautiful set pieces. All the characters focused on in this season were addressed in the first season but not developed. Karen and Tsukihi were just pushing Araragi at the end of every arc in Bakemonogatari and Shinobu didn't say a word.


Karen is a strong character who constantly tries to better herself similar to Rock Lee from Naruto (speaking of doing too many hand stands). She can at points be tsundere but for the most part is happy go lucky and whimsical in nature. Later in the Tsukihi Pheonix arc is where she really shines as her conflict has been resolved and she is allowed to be herself. She has this fun attitude and just makes me laugh and smile. Though i have noticed a trend throughout this series that characters seem to become so much better once their issues have been addressed, its like your waiting for their issue to be fixed so you can see if you truly like them.


Shinobu is the next character I will address as she is the next to be developed, she is just what I was wanting out of her. A character which knows that they have fallen from grace but refuses to accept this and still exudes power and superiority. She does not want to admit she wants to help a human and thus demands that Arraragi command her to do what he wants so that she feels she has no choice and doesn't have to acknowledge that she has fallen to his level. She is a cute tsundere character that admits to being tsundere as most characters in the show do. Her voice actor is great and it fits that role of a vastly superior yet young person. I loved every moment that she was once screen.


Tsukihi is the last character I will address, she is funny in the way that she is psychotic in many ways, when she walks in to find Araragi and Shinobu in a bath together she comes back with a knife ready to murder Shinobu and Araragi, when the infamous toothbrush scene comes up she asks what they are doing in a demented way before going to the store to buy an Awl. She is a character that though quite tsundere and just as psycho bitch as Senjougahara still loves Araragi as a brother. Tsukihi was the only character so far that actually was fleshed out as her character really is before and during her arc, save for Hanekawa though she had her issue addressed before the show began.


This show had a large amount of fan service in it, though in my opinion it was fine because it matched the overall tone of this season. It was happy, awkward, and just plain weird at points

But that is how the show is, there aren't many other shows where in one episode you can get a philosophical talk, loli fanservice, imouto fanservice, beautiful artwork, amazing fight scenes, and hilarious visuals. There just aren't many out there. Whereas the first season was something you really should sit back and watch to admire the set pieces and the conversations, this season focused much more on fanservice, and hilarious visuals. Which made it a fun ride all the way through.


Also up for mentioning is the Karen bee opening which I loved on a visual level and an auditory level, to the point that I downloaded the song to my phone and put in my ever growing anime song playlist. 


This show really should be watched, especially if you enjoyed the first season.


Ratings:

Animation: 9 (not as abstract as season one, more grounded)

Characters: 10 (in my opinion the characters were better though I just love these more this go round)

Sound: 8 (Just as good as the first season with the only standout track being the Karen bee opening)

Enjoyment: 10 (this honestly barely missed going into my top five favorites)

-----------------

Overall: 9.25

Nisemonogatari  review 
Nisemonogatari is the most bold piece of puzzle from the Monogatari Series  were the author used a visual vocabulary to relay a message for the viewer. That visual vocabulary consists in fanservice and some chaotic fights between Araragi and his sisters.
What was the purpose of using such a daring concept in his writing style? Well all the fanservice used had a purpose and meaning to answer Araragi’s doubts and feelings about his two sisters Karen and Tsuki. 
The series portrayed different insights of Araragi’s emotional state starting with Nadeko’s attempt to seduce him with no effect at all in the endto the brother-sister  daring kiss and boobs touch. Believe it or not these actions were well used in nisemonogatari for the plot giving a meaning to the story  and helping with the characterization of Araragi and his sisters Karen and Tsuki.


Nisemonogatari beside the daring fanservice used to convey a message introduced  new characters that will have a lot of influence in the next series Kaiki ,Kagenui and Yotsugi. The anime also presented a piece of  puzzle from Senjougahara’s past called Kaiki and with the confrontation between them  ,she faced  her past adding a new level to her characterization. 


Nisemonogatari also puts in discussion the aspect of morals between humans. As a example the dialogue scenes between Kaiki and Senjougahara were they both criticize the naivity of  the middle school students who were exorted for money by a con artist.The breaking of the moral line between incest and brother sister love is put in the spotlight with Araragi’s actions and visual vocabulary used by the author.


Nise as the name suggest puts in the spotlight the discussion if the fake is better than the real one. Well with the help of our character Araragi and with Kaiki’s actions the message becomes more like a  lesson of philosophy for the viewer.

The chaotic fight between Araragi and his sister Karen is another lesson of philosophy about what means to be strong. It’s not all about power and force brute as long as your conviction and mind is weak that’s what the message the fight portrayed .


In the end Nisemonogatari despite it’s overused fanservice has an important role in creating a bridge that connects the other series to the final destination called Monogatari series. It presented an insight to Araragi’s family and delivered a lesson of morality and philosophy about brother-sister love and contrast between fake and real.

***This is a spoiler free review***
After re-watching this season multiple times, I have a new understanding of how important this season of Monogatari is to the series as a whole. Some of the most important character development occurs in this season and it unfortunately gets looked over.
Story: 9/10
I find it very hard to take people’s criticism of this season seriously when all they boil it down to is “that fanservice season”. I don’t see how you are able to downplay all the extraordinarily important character development moments (Araragi and other characters testing the fire sister’s justice resolve, Shinobu opening up to Araragi for the firsttime since the film, ext) just because there is more fanservice in this season than the others. On top of that, the fanservice involving Araragi’s sisters is revelant to another important plot point to the series; the home environment and relationship between the siblings due to their absent parents. In such an environment where the parent figures are absent, it is very plausible for a relationship like this to occur. To say the show is “bad for having it” is like saying Shawshank Redemption is bad because it takes place in jail.

This season shows us so many important key moments in character development. These moments help define key actions later on in the series. Yes there is fanservice and if that bothers you then stop watching Monogatari as a whole because it is a part of its identity.


Animation: 10/10


I didn’t think I would ever consider something “perfect”, that was until I saw the animation in this show. The animation in this anime is very well done. It’s not only the quality of each scene but also the angle of the shots, the transitions between text to shot, the lighting, everything is just so well done it’s very hard to understand how well the animation studio did. Each scene is drawn and produced so well that if seen from across the room you might think it was on par with a budget of a movie rather than an ongoing show. Each character is very appealing to watch and even the very action orientated scenes flow smoothly. This is by far one of the best looking anime’s I have ever experienced.


Sound: 9.3/10


This anime is about talking (some of the conversations literally last 15 minutes) so you're going to want to enjoy what you are listening to right? Good thing Nisemonogatari has your back. The opening and closing themes are all very enjoyable to listen to as it ranges from j-pop to jazzy songs (I especially liked Tsukihi's opening). The voice acting is also very well done as all the characters had corresponding voices that seemed to fit correctly with the main star being Koyomi's voice actor. He once again brings out Koyomi's every emotion flawlessly without it coming off as fake or forced. For a show that relies so much on just character interaction, the voice acting really helped these long conversations shine. Overall the sound for this anime was well above par.


Characters: 8.5/10


The recurring characters personalities are just as enjoyable as they were in the previous season. In this season, we are introduced to Koyomi’s sisters and get to know the vampire Shinobu much more in-deph. Koyomi’s sisters range from an athletic tomboy who fights for what’s right to a very clever and masochist girl who aids her sister. I especially loved Karen as the minute we were introduced to her I knew I was going to love her character. Each gets a plethora amount of character development time to fully develop. The vampire Shinobu plays a much bigger role in this season. She also has a masochist-like personality that likes to play tricks on Koyomi. The new characters introduced this season are very well written and a joy to watch interact with Koyomi. I just wished the characters from Bakemonogatari played a bigger roll in the plot.


Overall: 9.3/10


While Bakemonogatari will remain one of my all-time favorites, Nisemonogatari will remind me that something so different can be just as good. With the characters written so well, animation being perfect, and voice acting exceeding my expectations, this is an anime you do not want to miss out on. I do however strongly encourage watching Bakemonogatari first as you might be very lost not doing so when starting Nisemonogatari.


Enjoyment: 9.5/10


Thanks for reading my review! If you liked my writing style, would like to see some other reviews, or just want to talk, please stop by my page!


Sincerely,

Awesome Drummer

So I was 247 characters into this review when i had to stop and go back and re-read my review of Bakemonogatari to confirm the two pretty much said the very same thing. This gave birth to the thought that one really REALLY should watch the first series before watching this one. Not that it's diminished without it, on the contrary; the mark of an anime as brilliant as this is that one need not have any prior information or experience with the series to enjoy either, or any of them as told from a non linear point of view as I've only watched Bakemonogatariand Nisemonogatari as of this review. 

Which, finally, brings me to my point. You already know you're going to watch it. You watched the first series didn't you? If you didn't then you should BUT you don't need to, in case you have some sort of aversion to watching first series or quality anime.

And if you did, then you already know you want to see more. The only issue is crunchyroll not having the last three episodes of Bakemonogatari and Nisemonogatari not directly filling those blanks. Which, I kind of liked because it meant I had to pay attention and learn information to fill in said blanks. 

My only real complaint is it's not for everyone, some with triggers that require warnings may have issue with some scenes and subject matter. 

Other than that WATCH IT! IT'S GREAT AND A PERFECT EXAMPLE OF WHY I STILL WATCH ANIME AFTER NEARLY FOUR DECADES!

Bakemonogatari became a massive hit in the anime industry due to just how well-polished it was. Its beautiful animation and catchy music helped elevate the impact of its well-developed storyline, memorable characters, and unusually-captivating dialogue. 
The main series director of Nisemonogatari, Tomoyuki Itamura, worked on a few episodes of Bakemonogatari before tackling this series. It seems like he understood the basics - he made sure we got to see all the old cast and their interactions with Araragi, as well as making sure the art and sound remained above average.
However, it seems that Tomoyuki had some fetishes he wanted satisfied as well, letting certain importantelements of Bake take a backseat in favor of his sexual gratification.


The first thing one might notice about Nisemonogatari is that it only covers two arcs over the course of eleven episodes. The first seven-episode arc, "Karen Bee", spends its first three episodes reminding us of the main cast of Bake and what they look like naked. The majority of these episodes is entertaining, but really just filler.


These episodes aren't completely filler or skippable due to some subtle details that add up throughout the episodes, but at least a full episode of this arc could have been knocked off with more tight summarization without the story losing anything. However, once "Karen Bee" picks up, it remains as captivating due to its supernatural elements and story as Bake was.


The second arc opens on what is basically fanservicy filler (*cough* toothbrush *cough*) that could be recapped in about five minutes, but since I enjoyed it and it's so infamous to the franchise I'm more forgiving of it then the first arc's filler. I ended up preferring the second arc over the first arc for having less filler and getting right to the point. It distinctively felt more like Bake, which is a great thing.


Overall, I do recommend this second season to anyone who enjoyed Bake. While the focus is lost a bit in favor of sexual deviancy and long chains of dialogue, the filler of the story at least has some entertainment value. Even though the overall story and introduction of our new characters starts out weaker then Bake, you'll come to appreciate them and care about their struggles by the end.

With the release of Bakemonogatari in 2009 Studio Shaft had created an anime that would forever change the way anime fans view the company. Bakemonogatari was very unique in both style and execution. With no other anime doing what it had done or, at least, not in the same fashion. Needless to say, it was a phenomenal success. So the announcement and release of a sequel, should be far from surprising.
Nisemonogatari picks up exactly where Bakemonogatari left off. Although, that is to say, with the main character Araragi conversing with many different characters in hilarious ways. The plot in this show is not overarching buttold in many minor arcs. Allowing for most of this show to be seen out of order, although most would probably not recommend it even though it is entirely possible.


All of the characters from the previous season are present but more are added while others sacrifice screen time. The largest of these being Nadeko who only shows up for a single five minute scene in one episode. The “new” characters are Shinobu and the Araragi sisters, Karen and Tsukihi. I say “new” because while these characters were present in Bakemonogatari they were simply names with a seiyuu. They had no development, practically no lines, and absolutely no story. They were simply just there.


This is a second season though, so chances are if you enjoyed the first season you will enjoy the second season. Also the extraordinarily increased production and animation quality certainly make this a standout. However, there are a few notable differences from the previous season.


First and foremost being the plot and structure. Most of the season feels like filler content, with nothing really happening plot wise. These episodes consist of nothing but essentially pointless character interactions. While that might sound negative, it in fact is the opposite. I said in my Bakemonogatari review that the best aspects of the show are it’s characters and dialogue, while it’s plot was it’s downfall. Nisemonogatari seems to fix that for the most part.


The new characters introduced are all fun and quirky with Shinobu being the standout in my opinion. Only person more interesting and enjoyable on screen than Shinobu, is Hitagi herself.


I have to make a comment on the fan service. Nisemonogatari seemed to have more fan service in it’s first four episodes than the entirety of Bake. That’s not even including the infamous “toothbrush scene”. However, all things considered the one thing I will give credit to this series, is how unique it is. Even when it comes to the fan service it’s done in such an interesting an artistic way, you could make up an entirely different name for it. This whole series seems to be in a genre of it’s own already. Despite my complains though, it doesn’t hamper my enjoyment, but at the same time, it doesn’t enhance it either.


Overall Nisemonogatari is a fantastic addition to the Monogarai series. It was able to keep the charm of the original series while adding new elements and characters without feeling forced.


Some people disliked the change in direction, but I think it’s heading down a good path.
